abstract: Supreme Court will hear case brought by Oklahoma prisoners challenging use of sedative midazolam in executions, which some medical experts say cannot be counted on to induce deep unconsciousness before lethal injection of painful agents; court has not revisited issue of lethal injections since 2008 decision, in which they determined that procedure does not constitute cruel and unusual punishment.
lead_paragraph: Three convicted murderers are fighting the use of midazolam in executions, which experts say cannot reliably cause deep unconsciousness.

headline.main: Justices to Hear Challenge That Argues Lethal-Injection Drug Causes Agony
headline.print_headline: Justices to Hear Challenge That Argues Execution Drug Causes Agony

snippet: Three convicted murderers are fighting the use of midazolam in executions, which experts say cannot reliably cause deep unconsciousness.
